classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Davis

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Carter

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient has presented for a general check-up.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that things have not been going too well since the last appointment, noting that his blood sugars have been unstable and his back pain is worse. Over the last couple of weeks, his levels have been berween 180 and 250, but states that sometimes around midday it gets down to around 110 or 120. He has not experienced any sugar lows. 

With regard to back pain, it is mostly on the right side, he describes that it feels like a stabbing pain and is worse when he moves or stands up after sitting for too long. He mentions some tingling down his right leg but this is not constant. 

He adds that his diet has not been ideal lately, which may be contributing to his cholesterol levels, but he is working on it. 

He is currently taking metformin twice daily and lisinopril daily to manage blood pressure.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Metformin (current) (1000mg, BID)

Lisinopril (current) (20 mg, QD)

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: There is some mild tenderness noted on palpation around the right paraspinal muscles. There is no obvious deformity. The range of motion is slightly limited on forward bending. The straight leg raise test is negative bilaterally. Patient's reflexes are intact. There is mildly decreased sensation noted along the right lateral thigh. There is some muscle strain and some nerve irritation.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patient's current blood pressure is 144/90, which is slightly high.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
Recent blood results from last week show that A1C was 8.4%, this is up slightly from the previous level of 7.7% which was about three months ago.

The MRI performed two weeks ago shows mild to moderate degenerative disc disease at L4-L5 with slight bulging disc, there is no significant nerve compression. This is consistent with the patient's symptoms.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Diabetes

As the patient's A1C has increased, adding Jardiance is recommended. This will help to lower blood sugar and reduces heart risks. Possible side effects include initial increased urination and some slight dizziness but most tolerate it well. The patient is advised to stay hydrated. 

Slight bulging disc

The MRI shows that there is no severe compression, this means that the pain can be managed conservatively with physical therapy and medication. Naproxen can also be taken as needed and stretching exercises have been provided.

High blood pressure

With regards to high blood pressure, it will continue to be monitored. A second medication may be needed in future if it does not come down. 

High cholesterol

Cholesterol is also slightly high; the patient has been encouraged to make dietary adjustment and is instructed to continue taking the statin, and lipids will be rechecked in three months. 

The patent will follow up in 4 weeks to see how they are doing with the new medication and physical therapy.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Ms Bennet

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Female

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Evans

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: New Patient

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents to establish care.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes about 10 years ago. Her most recent A1C reading was 8.2%, up from 7.5% six months prior. She takes metformin twice daily and glipizide daily. She reports that the metformin upsets her stomach, but that this is bearable.

She explains that her blood pressure has been high for around five years. She takes lisinopril daily. She occasionally experiences a cough with this medication which she describes as annoying but not severe. She monitors her blood pressure at home regularly and reports recent readings as 140/85-90, but that this can be higher when she is stressed.

She was formally diagnosed with anxiety around seven years ago and uses escitalopram daily, which she finds helps a bit. She has previously tried therapy but has not continued it while moving areas.

She reports joint pain, mainly in the hands and knees, which has been bothering her more recently. This is worse in the mornings and she describes her joints as stiff. She reports slight swelling around her knuckles, but no extreme swelling.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: Approximately eight years ago she had successful gallbladder surgery. She also describes having seasonal allergies.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Metformin (current) (1,000mg, BID)

Glipizide (current) (5mg, QD)

Lisinopril (current) (20m, QD)

Escitalopram (current) (10mg, QD)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer: In regards to family history, her mother has rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes, while her father has high cholesterol and had a heart attack in his sixties. She has recently relocated to the area from Chicago.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: Heart rate and rhythm is regular and without murmurs.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Clear breath sounds noted bilaterally.

classifications.title: Neurological
classifications.answer: Gait was normal, sensations were intact to light touch, and her reflexes were symmetrical.

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: When examining the extremities, bilateral mild swelling was noted at the proximal interphalangeal joints, alongside mild tenderness. Knees were tender and mild crepitus was noted bilaterally.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Abdomen is soft and non-tender, without palpable masses. Scars from prior laparoscopic gallbladder surgery is noted.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: Pupils are equal and reactive. Her oral mucosa is moist and no dental issues were noted. Her neck is supple, with normal thyroid size and no lymph nodes palpable.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: Blood pressure is 140/88, slightly elevated, pulse is 78, respiratory rate is 16 and her temperature is 36.8°C.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient appears alert, co-operative, and without acute distress.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Kidney function was slightly reduced but stable at 78. Cholesterol panel showed LDL at 135mg/dL, HDL at 42mg/dL and triglycerides at 160mg/dL

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Diabetes: As A1C is elevated, a medication such as Ozempic is recommended as a weekly injectable to help to control blood sugars. Additionally this may cause some weight loss. Typically this is less painful then insulin injections as the needle is smaller, so will likely only cause mild discomfort.

High blood pressure: In order to better manage the bothersome cough caused by the lisinopril, it is advised to switch to losartan as this has similar benefits without being linked to coughs.

Anxiety: A referral to a local therapist has been made, and the patient has been encouraged to discuss medication changes at a later date if necessary. Sleep may be disrupted due to anxiety, she is advised to keep a sleep journal to be reviewed at the next visit.

Joint pain: In order to establish whether this pain is linked with rheumatoid arthritis, further inflammatory lab tests have been ordered, including rheumatoid factor, ESR and CRP. In order to manage her pain in the mean time, a prescription for naproxen (500mg as needed, with food) has been issued. If labs return normal, then a rheumatology referral will be considered.

High cholesterol: As LDL and triglycerides are mildly elevated, in combination with her family history of heart disease it is recommended to consider medication for cholesterol management in the future. Dietary modifications are recommended in the mean time, with these tests repeated in three months.

Laboratory tests will be taken today and the patient will follow up in four weeks.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mrs Collins

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Female

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Reynolds

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for a routine check-up.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that she has been experiencing fatigue and is lacking energy to do things, particularly in the afternoons. She notes that there have been no changes in her routine or increase in stress, but that her sleep is not always consistent and she sometimes has trouble falling asleep.

She is currently takeing hydrochlorothiazide 25mg to manage her blood pressure.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: The patient has been monitoring her blood pressure at home, typically with scores around 130/80.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Hydrochlorothiazide (current) (25mg, QD)

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: Regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs or extra heart sounds. Pulses are normal bilaterally.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: lungs are clear bilaterally, there normal breath sounds with no wheezing or crackles noted.

classifications.title: Neurological
classifications.answer: Strength is intact in upper and lower extremities, reflexes are symmetric and normal.

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: No swelling in extremities.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds are normal, there are no palpable masses.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: Pupils are equal and reactive. Oral mucosa is pink and moist, with no abnormalities noted. Neck is supple with no palpable lymphadenopathy or thyroid enlargement. Physical exam overall appears entirely normal.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patient's blood pressure today is 134/82. Vital signs reviewed previously are stable.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: She appears well, alert, cooperative, and in no acute distress.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: The most recent blood tests were last checked 6 months ago, the results for haemoglobin, thyroid, and vitamin levels were normal.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Fatigue

Hydrochlorothiazide will be continued as blood pressure is stable. Given the ongoing fatigue, labs will be repeated including complete blood count, thyroid stimulating hormone, vitamin D and basic metabolic panel, as well as iron levels to rule out mild anaemia. Sleep hygiene strategies are discussed, such as avoiding using electronics close to bed time and maintaining a consistent sleep schedule.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Harris

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Kim

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: New Patient

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents to establish care.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient reports not having had a check-up in a while. He reports mild fatigue, but no major issues. He takes no regular medications, but does take vitamin supplements.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: He is unaware of any previous chronic conditions. He reports having his appendix removed due to appendicitis approximately 20 years ago.

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer:
There is no known family history of cancer or diabetes. His father has hypertension.

He does not smoke and consumes 1-2 alcoholic drinks per week socially. He currently works as an accountant and engages in regular walking.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: Regular heart rate and rhythm, with no murmurs or abnormal sounds noted.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Lungs were clear bilaterally with equal breath sounds, no wheezing, and no crackles.

classifications.title: Neurological
classifications.answer: Strength was 5/5 across all extremities, reflexes were normal and symmetrical, and sensation was intact.

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: When examining the extremities, no oedema was noted and pulse was palpable bilaterally. Skin was normal with no rashes or suspicious lesions.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Abdomen was soft and non-tender with no palpable masses or organomegaly. Bowel sounds were normal.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: Pupils are equal and reactive, oral mucosa is pink and moist, there are no signs of lesions, dentition is in good condition, and the neck is supple without palpable lymphadenopathy or thyroid enlargement.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: Blood pressure is 126/78, pulse is 72bpm, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and temperature is 36.9°C. All within normal limits.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient appears well-nourished, healthy, alert, oriented and without acute distress.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Following blood tests, his complete blood count was normal, haemoglobin was 14.8g/dL, white cell count was normal at 6,000, and platelets were normal at 220,000. His cholesterol panel was mostly normal. LDL was 112mg/dL, slightly higher than the ideal 100mg/dL. HDL was good at 58mg/dL, and triglycerides were within normal limits at 140mg/dL. Blood glucose was normal at 88mg/dL, and kidney and liver function tests were normal.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer: Routine review: Cholesterol tests will be repeated in 6 months to reassess. He is advised that multivitamins are recommended for those without a balanced diet, which may not be necessary for him as his diet appears to be balanced. During winter months, he is advised to consider supplementing vitamin D (1,000IU daily) as sun exposure is limited. He is advised to practice good sleep hygiene in order to improve his sleep, including limiting screen use before bed and implementing consistent sleep schedules. He is also advised to consider relaxation techniques such as meditation or yoga in order to manage his stress. Finally, he is advised to engage in 30 minutes of moderate exercise daily in association with a balanced diet in order to reduce his LDL. Patient will return for an annual physical next year, and will contact the clinic if symptoms change.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Andrews

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Patel

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Follow-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for evaluation of chest pain and shortness of breath.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient describes both chest pain and shortness of breath returning over the past few weeks. He describes this as intermittent, happening a few times per week and worse while walking or climbing upstairs. He also reports becoming winded more easily. During these episodes he has used nitroglycerin a few times, but he feels it is less effective than it was previously. He does describe it still helping a little bit. He also reports swelling of the ankles, especially during the evening, which his wife has mentioned to him. He explains that he sometimes forgets to take his furosemide (40mg twice daily) and has subsequently missed some doses. He reports lower energy levels recently and has needed to take naps in the day despite feeling as though he has slept okay through the night.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: He had a cardiac catheterisation in the RCA and a stent fitted approximately two years ago.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Furosemide (current) (40mg, BID)

Nitroglycerin (current)

Carvedilol (current) (12.5mg, BID)

Entresto (current) (49/51mg, BID)

Lasix (current)

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: Heart has a regular rhythm with a mild S3 gallop noted which is consistent with fluid overload.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Lungs sound clear at rest with no crackles or fluid sounds.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Abdomen is soft and non-tender, however mild fullness was noted, possibly mild ascites developing.

classifications.title: Genitourinary
classifications.answer: Upon examination of the legs, mild-to-moderate bilateral oedema was noted up to the mid-shins.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: Heart rate is 82 and blood pressure is 138/84, which is slightly elevated but stable. Respiratory rate is normal at 16 breaths per minute.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient is alert, conversational and comfortable at rest.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
BNP levels are elevated at 1,200, up from 900 previously. Potassium and kidney function look good with potassium at 4.1 and creatinine stable at 1.0. LDL has improved to 95, down from 110 previously. The statin seems to be working well. 

Echocardiogram from two weeks ago showed that his ejection fraction came back down slightly to 35% from 40% six months ago which may explain the worsening symptoms.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Exertional angina: As the patient's angina symptoms are returning despite the use of nitroglycerin, a repeat cardiac catheterisation has been schedules to reassess coronary arteries and to ensure that his stent is still open and no blockages are present. This will be coordinated with cardiology today and will likely be conducted as an outpatient. To support the function of the heart, he is advised to maintain compliance with carvedilol, entresto and lasix and has been encouraged to set alarms for these medications on his phone.

Fluid retention: As the current dose of furosemide is not appropriately managing his oedema the dose has been increased from 40mg twice daily, to 60mg twice daily. Electrolytes, especially potassium, will be monitored during this increase with labs rechecked in one week. He was informed that he may notice increased urination. He is advised to consider restricting his dietary sodium to under 2,000mg per day and manage his activities throughout the day to assist in reducing the oedema and fatigue.

The patient will return in a week for follow-up labs.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Bennett

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Carter

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for a routine check-up.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that things have been going well since the last visit. He is trying to moderate his salt intake. He has been taking his blood pressure at home, and reports it to be around 130/80, he continues to measure it every couple of days. He refutes experiencing any chest pain but does get some slight shortness of breath, though this is only when he is exerting himself, such as rushing upstairs, and he does not find it unsual. There is no shortness of breath at rest or during typical activities. He has been walking his dog daily but feels that he could improve his level of exercise.

He is currently taking losartan in the mornings and feels that it is working well. There have been no side effects. He is also on atorvastatin which is taken daily before bed; it is being tolerated well with no new muscle aches or side effects.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Losartan (current) (50mg daily)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer: The patient walks his dog on most days.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: The heart is auscultated; there is a good regular rhythm and there are no murmurs or extra sounds heard.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: The lungs are auscultated; they are clear bilaterally with no issues.

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: The ankles are examined, there is no noticeable swelling or oedema.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: His blood pressure today is 132/80, with the heart rate steady at 74bpm, this is nice and stable.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient looks well, comfortable, alert, oriented, and there is no acute distress noted.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Labs from 6 months ago were excellent. Cholesterol numbers were good; LDL was at 95, HDL was 50, triglycerides were 120.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Upon physical examination, everything looks excellent and is stable. As blood pressure and cholesterol have been consistently well-controlled, there is not much that needs to be adjusted. He has been reassured that walking is good exercise but has been encouraged to gradually increase the intensity and distance. It is advised that if a balanced diet is maintained, supplements are not necessary, but vitamin D can be beneficial, particularly during winter, taken at 1000IU daily. 

The patient will follow-up in 6 months for a routine review.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Henderson

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of chest pain and leg swelling.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports worsening chest pain, he describes it as sharper and notes that it comes on more frequently, especially with any type of activity, even when walking to the bathroom. The pain is substernal and radiating to the left arm. He is also experiencing tightness in his jaw which has been a cause for concern. 

There has been no improvement in the leg swelling since the last visit, he notes that it has worsened; his shoes now barely fit. He has also noticed shortness of breath, especially at night, and finds lying on his back to be difficult. 

He mentions that he has been experiencing some emotional distress due to his health, as well as some troubles he has been having with his son. 

He is taking all of his current medications as prescribed, this includes lisinopril, metoprolol, furosemide, aspirin. He is also taking nitroglycerin which he is using up to three or four times a day, feeling that

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Lisinopril (current)

Metoprolol (current)

Furosemide (current)

Aspirin (current)

Nitroglycerin (current, PRN)

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
Recent lab tests were conducted last week; creatinine has increased slightly and potassium is still borderline. This needs to be monitored closely. BNP is also elevated, this is a marker for heart failure. 

The latest echocardiagram showed some progression of the left ventricular dysfunction.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Possible acute coronary syndrome

The patient has been using nitroglycerin up to four times a day, antianginal therapy will need to be adjusted. The elevation of BNP combined with the symptoms reported suggests a worsening of the condition. The recent ECG also needs to be reviewed. The symptoms and lab results indicate a need for immediate intervention. Medications will need to be adjusted and further testing must be considered. Jaw tightness is also a concern; acute coronary syndrome must be ruled out. 

An ECG needs to be preformed, and troponin levels should be repeated. The last stress test was 6 months ago and should be repeated. A coronary CT angiogram will be performed; given the jaw tightness and increased chest pain, the coronary arteries need to be further investigated. Fluid retention also needs to be addressed, this may require an increase in furosemide dosage and the addition of a potassium supplement. 

Orthopnoea is also very concerning; oxygen therapy should be considered. This will be discussed following the ECG and stress test results. 


Diet also needs to be discussed, a low sodium, fluid restricted diet is advised. Weight should also be monitored daily. The patient has been encouraged to be stricter with diet and managing salt intake. Activity level is also discussed; the chest pain is limiting but balance needs to be found between rest and gentle activity.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mr Johnson

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Lee

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Referral

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient has presented for a cardiovascular assessment following a referral from primary care.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient was referred by his primary care physician regarding blood pressure and palpitations. He describes the palpitations as feeling like his heart skips a beat, or is racing, and sometimes it thumps very hard. These episodes occur approximately two or three times a week, lasting a few minutes, ten at most. It is not constant but unsettling when it happens. He has noticed that stress seems to trigger these episodes, and sometimes following a large meal or drinking too much coffee. Lacking sleep can also be a trigger. Dr Smith informed him that his blood pressure was elevated at 140/90. He refutes having any other medical conditions though sometimes feels lightheaded which he had attributed to growing older. He notes that he occasionally experiences shortness of breath when he walks uphill.

He attempts to eat healthily but admits that it is sometimes easier to grab something quick and that he probably uses too much salt, something his wife points out to him. He is also fond of burger and fries.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: The heart is auscultated; the sounds are somewhat irregular.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patient's blood pressure today is 142/92.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Blood pressure assessment

Based on the physical examination, further investigated is required. An ECG will be requested, a Holter monitor to track heart rhythm over 24 hours, as well as a full blood panel including cholesterol, electrolytes, kidney function, and thyroid levels. A stress test will also be performed to investigation the shortness of breath experienced with exertion, and an echocardiogram will provide a detailed view of the structure and function of the heart. Based on the results of these tests, a treatment plan will be developed. Consideration will be given to blood pressure medication, depending on Holter results, which would regulate the rhythm. Lifestyle changes will also be discussed, this would include things like diet, exercise, and stress management. This will all be discussed in detailed once the results are available. He has been instructed to keep a log of the palpitations, noting how long they last and any potential triggers; this will help in interpreting the Holter monitor results. Episodes of shortness of breath should also be logged. He is advised to reduce caffeine intake, and in the instance of any severe chest pain, shortness of breath, or lightheadedness resulting in fainting he should go to the ER immediately. 

The patient will follow-up in two weeks to review the results.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Sarah

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Female

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Ramirez

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Follow-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for a follow up regarding heavy menstrual bleeding and associated symptoms.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that she has been feeling stressed as the bleeding has not stopped and she is still experiencing intense cramping and constant nausea. The bleeding is not as heavy as it was initially, but it is a steady flow requiring the changing of sanitary towels every few hours. She explains that the cramps are located mostly centrally in the lower abdomen, giving them a pain score of 7, sometimes 8, out of 10. The nausea is constant and described as feeling queasy all the time, though it is not paired with vomiting. There is a presence of fatigue, she struggles to make it through the day; she wakes up several times per night, either from the cramps, or because she cannot get comfortable, and also due to the worry this condition is causing. She is still experiencing hot flashes, particularly at night, and is waking up drenched in sweat. Her diet has been affected as she finds it difficult to eat much with the nausea, noting a tendency to opt for crackers and ginger ale, as well as some meals her husband may cook. She expresses feeling overwhelmed, her husband is a great support but she feels like a burden. Additionally, she has been experiencing constipation which she attributes to being a side effect of the pain medication. 

The patient is still taking progesterone and pain medication. She has alarms set to remind her to take all of her medications.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Progesterone (current)

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
The recent blood results show that there is some mild anaemia, as was suspected.

The ultrasound results from last week show that the fibroid has grown slightly, but it is still within the previously discussed range. It will continue to be monitored closely.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Uterine fibroids and menorrhagia

Treatment for nausea will be considered if it is interfering with eating, as it is important to consume enough nutrients. A pelvic will be performed, along with an ultrasound, to see if there any changes in the size of the fibroid. Blood tests will also be performed to check haemoglobin levels as the prolonged bleeding could potentially be causing anaemia. Medication can be prescribed to help with managing the constipation as it can cause cramps to worsen. Pain medication will also be adjusted. As the hot flashes are still occurring some hormone replacement therapy options or other medications can be considered which would help in management. Some counselling options can be discussed to aid in managing the emotional toll and offering additional support. A D&C procedure can be considered if the bleeding continues; this is a common procedure and the risks and benefits can be discussed before a decision is made. The patient has been encouraged to make contact with any concerns or questions.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Mrs. Peterson

classifications.title: Gender
classifications.answer: Female

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr. Simmons

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Follow-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient has presented for a follow-up of fertility treatment.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient has been taking letrozole for the past ten days. She mentions that she has had occasional slight headaches but has not had any significant side effects or symptoms. She reports no nausea or mood changes, but notes that her husband has mentioned that she has been somewhat irritable. She has been using the ovulation predictor kits daily for at home ovulation tracking, with them being mostly negative. She is currently on cycle day 12.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Letrozole (current)

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: The ultrasound scan performed today show that the follicles are responding well. The right ovary is 17mm, with the left ovary a little smaller at 10 or 11mm.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Fertility Treatment

The patient is responding well to the letrozole and the medication should be continued. She is encouraged to continue ovulation predictor testing at home. Timed intercourse should be started today continuing for the next three days to maximise chances of conception this cycle. She is informed that caffeine intake is generally fine, with one cup daily recommended. Alcohol should be limited or avoided around ovulation for safety. She is also encouraged to continue engaging with yoga or meditation in order to manage stress. 

She will return in a week for a progesterone check in order to confirm that ovulation occurred.

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for a follow-up regarding Crohn's disease.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that her symptoms have been unpredictable since the last appointment. She notes that she has been having intense stomach cramps and describes bathroom trips as exhausting. Some days she is rushing to the bathroom 8-10 times, this is mostly in the morning and is paired with a sharp pain. 

She has been trying to track her diet but has been finding it difficult as she feels that everything she eats seems to trigger something. She has lost 5kg over the past two months and finds that she is not experiencing much hunger, noting that nothing tastes good.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patient has lost 5kg in the past two months.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
The recent endoscopy shows some inflammation in the small intestine. The biopsies reveal signs consistent with the progression of Crohn's disease. 

The calprotectin levels are significantly high, indicating ongoing intestinal inflammation.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Crohn's disease progression

The recent imaging shows that there is some slight narrowing in the small intestine, so the treatment approach needs to be adjusted. The medication will be modified; this will include increasing the immunosuppressant dosage, as well as starting a new biologic therapy. This combination should help to manage inflammation more effectively. Some additional blood work will also be required to monitor the response to the medication changes, this will be performed weekly for the next month. She will also be referred to a nutritionist who can advise on a specialised diet for inflammatory bowel conditions to ensure that she is getting the proper nutrients required. 

The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in four weeks and additional imaging will be considered if symptoms persist.

classifications.answer:
The patient has been having irregular periods for about a year, which she notes worsened after she stopped taking birth control. She describes that her menstrual cycle sometimes skips a couple of months and then when they do come they are particularly heavy and she experiences intense cramping. 

She was taking birth control for about five years, but stopped taking it as she and her partner are considering trying for a baby soon.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, this was diagnosed 3 years ago and is being managed with levothyroxine.

classifications.title: Allergies
classifications.answer: Penicillin

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Levothyroxine (current)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer: The patient reports that she drinks alcohol about once a week, socially. She has never smoked. She consumes caffeine daily which she limits to one cup in the mornings. She practices yoga multiple times a week, walks her dog daily, and tries to eat healthily.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: The abdomen is soft and non-tender, there are no masses.

classifications.title: Genitourinary
classifications.answer: The pelvic exam shows a normal uterus. There is no cervical motion tenderness and no adnexal masses.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patients blood pressure today is 118/72, heart rate is 76. Everything looks normal.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Menstrual irregularities

PCOS could be a possible cause for an irregular menstrual cycle and some of the symptoms mentioned today. Blood tests will be performed today to investigate, these will include hormone levels, a thyroid panel. A pelvic ultrasound will be performed to get an image of the ovaries.

classifications.title: Name

classifications.answer: Male

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Grant

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of persistent abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient reports abdominal pain which has persisted for several months. It is described as a cramping pain present mostly in the lower abdomen. It is accompanied by frequent diarrhoea with urgency, occurring four or five times a day, sometimes more. There is also some blood and mucus present in the stool. He notes that he has lost weight, approximately 4.5kg in the last two months. He has experienced nausea but no vomiting.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Upon examination the abdomen is soft, but there is tenderness in the left lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness noted. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. There are no palpable masses but there is some mild guarding present.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: The patient self-reports a weight loss of 4.5kg over a period of 2 months.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer:
Recent blood results show that ESR and CRP are elevated, which indicates inflammation. Calprotectin is also high. CBC shows mild anaemia, but CMP is normal. 

The stool study is negative for bacterial infections, but there are elevated faecal leukocytes, which also indicate inflammation.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Ulcerative colitis

Given the symptoms and family history, there is concern about the possibility of inflammatory bowel disease, this will need to be further investigated. A colonoscopy will be arranged to visualise the colon and take biopsies, as well as a stool study to check for infections, inflammation and calprotectin levels. Blood work will also be performed, including a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, ESR and CRP. 

There are medical options to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms. Amino salicylate has been prescribed, it will be started on a low dose and adjusted as necessary. Long-term management should be considered. This condition requires ongoing monitoring and treatments. Regular follow-up appointments and colonoscopies will be performed to monitor disease activity. The risks and benefits of immunosuppressant medications will also be discussed if the initial medications do not work. 

Dietary modifications will also be discussed, such as a low-residue diet which can help to manage symptoms. A detailed list will be provided, but it is encouraged to avoid high-fibre foods, dairy products, and spicy foods during flare-ups. Foods will gradually be reintroduced as symptoms begin to improve. The patient is also advised that stress management techniques, such as yoga and meditations, can  also be helpful. Smoking should also be avoided as it can worsen the condition. Long-term risks have been explained as these can include strictures, fistulas, and an increased risk of colon cancer. 

The patient will follow-up in one month to check on symptoms and medication tolerance. Dietary modifications will also be discussed in detail.

classifications.answer: Referral

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of bowel changes following a referral from Dr Martin.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient mentions that they have been experiencing bowel changes over the past four or five months. She reports abdominal pains, digestive issues including bloating, diarrhoea and occasional constipation. These episodes are unpredictable. The abdominal pains are described as sharp at some times and dull at others, and it comes and goes. It is not consistent every day but is frequent, occurring several times a week. 

With regards to potential triggers, she considers that stress may be a potential factor. She has tried to pay attention to any foods that may be exacerbating the condition but has not been able to find any specific correlations. She feels that dairy sometimes worsens symptoms but not always.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: The abdomen is soft overall but mildly tender upon palpation in the right lower quadrant. There are no masses felt and no obvious guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: The eyes are mouth are examined, there is a slight pallor in the conjunctivae which is consistent with mild anaemia. Upon examination of the skin, there are no unusual rashes or legions.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient appears to be comfortable, slightly anxious but cooperative. There is a mild pallor noted.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Suspected inflammatory bowel disease

Considering the patient's symptoms, labs, and imaging, there is possibility of Crohn's disease or another similar condition. Dicycloverine will be prescribed to aid in managing cramping. A colonoscopy will be requested to further investigate the bowel. Any inflamed areas will be biopsied to confirm or rule out specific conditions. The patient is instructed to try a low-residue diet temporarily; avoiding nuts, seeds, popcorn, raw veggies, and other such things which might irritate the gut.

classifications.title: Name
classifications.answer: Alex

classifications.title: Consulting Physician
classifications.answer: Dr Smith

classifications.title: Consultation Type
classifications.answer: Follow-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of mood swings and sleep disruptions.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient had previously presented with anxiety but this has been improved by medication and has mostly been better. The mood swings are still present and still as intense. The patient describes that his mood can change in an instant and it can last for hours or sometimes days. He is still waking up in the middle of the night and is sometimes struggling to fall asleep, however, on some nights he sleeps for 12 hours. He notes that he has less racing thoughts now but that his energy levels vary; sometimes feeling like he is capable of doing anything, but other times struggling to even get out of bed. He describes his current mood at flat, a little tired, and somewhat irritated. he is not experiencing any unusual thoughts, hallucinations or delusions, but reports the presence of worrying and mood swings. 

He is currently taking sertraline for anxiety and lamotrigine for mood stabilisation, though he is not consistent with administration. He is still attending therapy.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Sertraline

Lamotrigine

classifications.title: Neurological
classifications.answer: The patients reflexes are normal, gait is normal, speech is also normal. There are no tremors notes. Cranial nerves are intact.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Labs performed last month show that thyroid levels are still within normal range. Vitamin D is a little low. The complete metabolic panel had normal results.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Mood swings

Lamotrigine may not yet be fully effective, it can take some time to reach therapeutic levels. The dosage will be increased slightly.

Low vitamin D can sometimes affect mood and energy levels; a vitamin D supplement will be prescribed and levels will be rechecked in a few months.

Sleep hygiene will be discussed and a referral for a sleep study will be given if needed. Medication can also be considered though daytime drowsiness should be avoided. 

It is also recommended to continue with therapy sessions. It is important to maintain that support system while medication is being adjusted. Some cognitive behavioural therapy techniques can also be used to help manage the mood swings. 

The patient will return in a month to reassess.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports their mood as up and down, and really unpredictable. They describe a combination of depression, anxiety, irritability and energy shifts during these mood swings; likening the swings to a cycle. They are also experiencing a lack of motivation which results in increased anxiety. Sleep has been unstable, sometimes falling asleep okay but waking up through the night, or tossing and turning for hours. 

The patient is currently taking Lamictal daily which is being tolerated well, though there is a report of occasional headaches which may be a side effect or possibly stress-related. They are also seeing a therapist, Karen, fortnightly which is described as slow-going.

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer: Lamictal (current) (100mg, QD)

classifications.title: Psychiatric
classifications.answer: No tremors or abnormal movements are noted. Mood appears to be mildly anxious. Their affect is congruent with mood, being slightly restricted but reactive. Their thought process is logical and coherent, there are no overt delusions or hallucinations evident, and insight is fair with judgment intact.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient appears a bit tired, mildly anxious but co-operative, slightly restless, shifting positions frequently, but is appropriately groomed. Their eye contact is intermittent but mostly good. Their speech is clear and maintains a normal rate and rhythm.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Thyroid panel was normal. TSH was fine at 2.1. Vitamin D was slightly low at 22, ideally this should be above 30. MRI was normal neurologically.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer: Mood swings: The patient's symptoms do not exclusively indicate only depression, a mood disorder such as bipolar II, or an anxiety disorder. As the current dosage of Lamictal (100mg daily) appears to have not significantly stabilised their moods, an increase has been issued (150mg daily). Vitamin D (2000IU daily) has been prescribed to help mood and energy. Trazodone (20 mg per night) will also be introduced as mild short-term treatment for sleep. The patient is encouraged to continue with therapy aiming for stress reduction strategies and techniques.

classifications.answer:
Metformin (current) (500mg, BID)

Lisinopril (current) (20mg, QD)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer:
The patient has no history of cancer, but his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 75. There is no knowledge of any other cancers or blood conditions.

He is a retired school teacher. He has never smoked and has only occasional alcohol use of about one glass of wine per week socially. He refutes any recreational drug use.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular
classifications.answer: Heart rate and rhythm is regular, without murmurs.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Lungs are clear to ascultation bilaterally, there are no abnormal breath sounds.

classifications.title: Musculoskeletal
classifications.answer: When examining the extremities pulses were palpable bilaterally and no oedema was noted. Skin examination was normal with no unusual bruising or petechiae noted.

classifications.title: Gastrointestinal
classifications.answer: Abdomen is soft and non-tender. Bowel sounds are normal. No palpable masses or hepatosplenomegaly.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: Pupils are equal and reactive. Oral mucosa is normal without lesions. Neck is supple with no palpable lymphadenopathy.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: Blood pressure is 134/82, heart rate is 74, respiratory rate is normal, and no fever was noted.

classifications.title: General Appearance
classifications.answer: The patient appears well-nourished, alert, and cooperative with no acute distress noted.

classifications.title: Diagnostic Tests & Imaging
classifications.answer: Blood work showed elevated white blood cell counts at 14,500 while the normal range is below 11,000. On a differential blood count lymphocytes are elevated but haemoglobin and platelets are within normal limits. The peripheral blood smear shows typical small lymphocytes consistent with CLL.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Suspected chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL):

This is usually slow-progressing and often requires only monitoring initially. To confirm diagnosis, further testing including flow cytometry and a CT scan have been ordered. Specialised blood testing will confirm the diagnosis and subtype, while the CT scan will investigate potential lymph node enlargement or organ involvement. Risks of the CT scan were explained as minimal with low-risk radiation exposure. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise. At this point, no further changes or restrictions are required. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled following the completion of the ordered tests.

They feel that the anxiety may be worse lately, they are having more trouble in trying to leave the house sometimes. This is general anxiety but is worse around people, resulting in self-consciousness and feeling that people are looking or judging. Some days are better, but other days they feel unmotivated and empty. They express a readiness to try another medication or adjustment of dosage. Sleep has still been disruptive, they are waking up a lot and falling asleep is difficult due to their mind racing. They are currently working at a coffee shop where there is a new manager and a lot of changes have been made, resulting in an increase of stress due to the chaos. They also mention that appetite has been irregular lately, some day they are not hungry, whereas others they are unable to stop eating.

The patient is currently taking sertraline every morning but is not sure that it is helping as much as it used to. They are still seeing Jenna fortnightly for therapy which is found to be helpful but is noted to be somewhat repetitive.

classifications.answer: Sertraline (current) (100mg, QD)

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Mood swings and anxiety

Since anxiety has worsened, something can be used to augment the sertraline, such as buspirone, 10mg twice daily, it is a mild medication which usually helps with symptoms of generalised anxiety. It can also help the antidepressant work better for anxiety. For sleep, a mild, low dose of trazodone, 50mg at night, to temporarily help to break the cycle of insomia.

classifications.answer: The patient describes increased chest discomfort, similar to that experienced before, which is intermittent. She describes these occurrences as lasting approximately five minutes and subsiding pretty quickly at rest. She describes breathlessness during these occurrences, but has not noticed dizziness. She reports swelling of the ankles, especially in the evenings, as well as a 2kg weight gain which she had attributed to holiday food. Her ankles have been swelling a lot and she describes them as feeling tight, but not tender. She refutes adherence issues regarding her medications. She has used her nitroglycerin two or three times in the past month, but dislikes the headaches that this causes her. She measures her blood pressure at home occasionally and reports this to be around 140/90 and sometimes higher. She reports occasionally high blood sugars in the morning, but overall feels her blood sugars are well controlled. She describes feeling more tired lately, but refutes palpitations.

She reports headaches following nitroglycerin use as well as some muscle pain, but otherwise does not report side effects when using her medications. She has recently seen her endocrinologist for her thyroid and was told that her hypothyroidism, which was diagnosed about ten years ago, was stable. She takes levothyroxine (100mg daily) to manage this. She is diabetic and takes metformin (500mg twice daily) for this.

classifications.answer: Tenderness noted in the upper middle of the abdomen, just below the ribs. No tenderness is noted on the lower sides. Bowel sounds are normal with no guarding, rigidity, or masses.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer: Stomach pain: Based on the symptoms described and the examination, it is possible that the patient has gastritis or a mild ulcer. In order to confirm, some labs have been ordered as well as a breath test for H. pylori. In the mean time it is advised that the patient avoid spicy foods, caffeine, and NSAIDs. A medication to reduce stomach acid has been prescribed to relieve the pain while investigations are conducted. The patient will return for a follow-up once results are available.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports that she has been doing well but has been experiencing some fatigue lately. It is not impacting her daily activities much, but she describes feeling wiped out by the late afternoon on most days. She refutes chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath, as well as any changes to her health since the last visit, but acknowledges some mild nausea caused by the medication. She has also had some aching in her joints, namely the knees and hands. 

The patient is currently taking ondansetron, twice daily, but admits to occasionally forgetting to take the evening dose.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: The patient is also taking levothyroxine for her thyroid and ibuprofen for occasional headaches. A right lumpectomy was performed two years ago, with chemotherapy initiated six months ago.

classifications.title: Allergies

Penicillin

Sulfonamides

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer: The patient is supported by her husband and children. She is still on leave from work and intends to return part-time next month. She drinks a beer approximately once a week, but refutes use of tobacco.

classifications.answer: The heart is auscultated and sounds good.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Fatigue

The fatigue could be a result of the chemotherapy; the patient has been encouraged to schedule short naps midday. The condition will continue to be monitored.

The patient will follow-up in four weeks.

classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of anxiety and depression.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient reports feeling unmotivated to do anything and struggling to get out of bed over the last six months or so, explaining that this has gotten worse over the past few weeks. She has a history of depression from when she was in collage years ago, and was treated with sertraline at the time. She stopped this after a year as, while she reports that it helped at first, she found that she was feeling numb and emotionally flat. She has not taken psychiatric medications since this. She reports eating more comfort foods recently, and gaining approximately 7kg. She describes feeling as though she is sleeping all of the time but still feeling exhausted. She refutes having thoughts of harming herself or others. She describes her blood sugars as being higher than usual. She also describes feeling generally overwhelmed by everything.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: The patient is diabetic and has hypertension, for which she takes metformin (500mg twice a day) and lisinopril (20mg daily) respectively. She reports having a C-section ten years ago, and no other surgeries. She also has asthma, and arthritis in her knees.

classifications.title: Allergies
classifications.answer: Latex

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Metformin (current) (500mg, BID)

Lisinopril (current) (20mg, QD)

Sertraline (past)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer:
The patient's mother has bipolar disorder.

She smokes approximately half a packet of cigarettes per day, and reports drinking with higher frequency lately. She describes drinking pretty much every day, but primarily in the evenings and not throughout the day. She refutes the use of recreational drugs. She is currently employed as a store manager, and finds that this is stressful. She lives alone with her son and her other family is living out of state, which she describes as hard.

Self-reported weight gain of 7kg.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Diabetes: As the patient reports higher than usual blood sugars recently, an A1C check has been ordered.

Depression and anxiety: The patient has expressed willingness to engage with both medication and therapy, and believes that a combination of both would be most effective for her. A follow-up to discuss this further will be arranged soon.

classifications.answer: Routine Check-up

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents for an evaluation of anxiety.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer:
The patient reports an increase in anxiety, explaining that there are some days he is unable to get out of bed. He describes that the anxiety comes in waves, but has been more constant as of late, especially in the mornings. He notes that he has been more irritable lately, something that his girlfriend has also noticed. Falling asleep has been okay, but he wakes around 3 or 4 AM and is unable to get back to sleep; this has been the case for about a month or so. He adds that his uncle, who he was close to, passed away last month, which has been a recent stressor. He describes that it has hit him harder than expected. He has lost 5kg over the past two months due to a lack of appetite. He has been smoking marijuana nightly to aid in sleep, he finds that it helps in falling asleep but he feels groggy in the mornings. 

He is still complying with use of sertraline every morning, but admits that he is less consistent with the clonazepam, missing a dose two or three times a week.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: There is a medical history of anxiety, depression, and acid reflux. An appendectomy was performed five years ago.

classifications.title: Allergies
classifications.answer: Penicillin

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Sertraline (current)

Clonazepam (current)

Omeprazole (current)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer: The patient has recently moved into a new apartment with his girlfriend. He notes that it is quieter, which helps. He is working as a freelance graphic designer and describes that money is tight. He quit smoking last year, and consumes alcohol maybe once a week. He has recently been using marijuana nightly to help him sleep. He does not engage in much exercise outside of walking the dog.

classifications.title: Cardiovascular

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Lungs are auscultated and sound normal.

classifications.answer: The patient is presenting no signs of distress.

classifications.title: Others
classifications.answer: Pupils are reactive.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer:
Blood pressure is 128/82, heart rate is 76. There is no tremor.
Self-reported weight loss of 5kg.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Anxiety 

Sertraline will be increased to 75mg. The patient will also be re-referred for therapy. 

Insomnia

Grogginess can worsen anxiety, so alternatives for marijuana will need to be explored. CBT-I (Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia) is suggested, as well as adjustment of medication. 

The patient will follow up in four weeks, or sooner if things worsen.

classifications.title: Reason for Visit
classifications.answer: The patient presents as a new patient for an evaluation of low mood.

classifications.title: History of Present Illness
classifications.answer: The patient describes feeling down since December, having little energy, and crying a lot. She experienced a break up in November and has been finding work to be overwhelming. She describes sleeping poorly, waking up at 3 or 4 in the morning and feeling wide awake. She has a reduced appetite, explaining that food doesn't taste like anything. She explains having felt sadness while at college and during exams, however feels that this is different. She describes thinking about disappearing, but states that she would not do anything to act on these thoughts. She currently takes norgestimate/ethinyl estradiol birth control pills. She describes having to drag herself out of bed most days.

classifications.title: Past Medical History
classifications.answer: The patient is asthmatic and had mononucleosis while in high school. She has had her wisdom teeth removed, but reports no other surgeries. She takes salbutamol as needed.

classifications.title: Allergies
classifications.answer: Penicillin

classifications.title: Medications
classifications.answer:
Norgestimate/ethinyl estradiol (current)

Salbutamol (current) (as needed)

classifications.title: Family & Social History
classifications.answer:
The patient's mother had depression and her uncle had bipolar disorder.

She describes drinking a little at weekends and having tried marijuana while at college. She refutes smoking, vaping, and recent use of recreational drugs. She lives with her sister in a split two-bedroom property. She works as a paralegal and finds this to be stressful.

classifications.title: Respiratory
classifications.answer: Breathing sounds clear with no tremor.

classifications.title: Vital Signs
classifications.answer: Pulse is 72 and blood pressure is 118/76.

classifications.title: Assessment & Plan
classifications.answer:
Depression: It appears from the symptoms described that the patient is experiencing a depressive episode. Treatment options include therapy such as CBT, and medications. A prescription for sertraline (25mg daily) was issued, and it was explained that while effective and generally well tolerated, side effects include nausea, mild headaches, and trouble sleeping. It was explained that usually patients notice a change in 2-4 weeks, with full effect becoming noticed after 6-8 weeks. She will be started on a low dose and monitored closely. She will also be referred to a therapist who specialises in CBT. This will be scheduled within the week, and it will be attempted to be scheduled for the afternoons to accommodate her work.

She will return for a follow up in 4 weeks.
